comment.author: 32605636@N06
comment._content: We'd love to know more about these three young men. We do know that Kenneth served in the United States military during World War 1 and that, unusually, all three brothers survived.

comment.author: 96752972@N00
comment._content:
KENNEDY Colin Leslie Grant : Service Number - 50650 : Place of Birth - Croydon QLD : Place of Enlistment - Brisbane QLD : Next of Kin - (Mother) KENNEDY Sophia
KENNEDY Glen Douglas Duff : Service Number - 4529 : Place of Birth - Croydon QLD : Place of Enlistment - Normanton QLD : Next of Kin - (Mother) KENNEDY Sophia

So, one enlisted fairly early, one much later.
Births

1885/C3104 Kennith James Kennedy James Maria Sophia Bertholina Hansen

comment.author: 96752972@N00
comment._content:
In 1908, Kenneth James was a miner, residing in Croydon. Disappears off the electoral rolls after that.
1925, Glen Douglas and Colin Leslie Grant are living in Queen Bess St, Buranda with their Mum. Colin is a motor mechanic and Glen is a grocer. Colin and his Mum enrolled there in 1919.

comment.author: 96752972@N00
comment._content: I would say that the image is a photographic montage.

comment.author: 32605636@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/96752972@N00]  We agree here that this photo must be a montage. There is an almost identical picture of Kenneth in our collection that might have been used to create the montage. It's really interesting to us, that these three all survived. It must have been unusual.

comment.author: 96752972@N00
comment._content:
Unusual, maybe, but not rare. When you look at the records for the two AIF boys, Colin Leslie arrived in France just a month before the Armistice (12 October 1918) and was only taken on strength on 1 April 1919, which was when most of the lads in France were getting ready to go home. (I know from the dates on my Grandad's photos that he was busy taking happy snaps in March and April 1919 before heading home via the Codford Camps.)
Colin served in WW2, but not overseas.
KENNEDY COLIN LESLIE GRANT : Service Number - Q272053 : Date of birth - 11 Jul 1899 : Place of birth - CROYDON QLD : Place of enlistment - QLD : Next of Kin - SCHULTZ IVY

Colin Leslie Grant Kennedy was interred in Pinnaroo on 13 August 1970.

comment.author: 96752972@N00
comment._content:
IN 1940, James K Kennedy, 53, single, born Australia was living in 206 Linden Avenue, Redwood City, San Mateo. He was a Construction Estimator in the construction industry. He'd been there in 1935 as well. He seems to have been living in a large apartment block.
I don't have this level of access to the 1920 and 1930 Federal Census, so can't place him anywhere definite in those years.

comment.author: 96752972@N00
comment._content:
From 1937 onwards, Glen Douglas Duff Kennedy and Ursula May Kennedy lived at 37 Victoria Terrace, Annerley. Glen was a storeman. They stayed there until at least 1977.

Colin Leslie stayed at the Queen Bess St address until 1949 (when he gave his occupation as Soldier), then in 1954 he is at 4th Avenue, Mt Isa, motor driver where he stays until the 1968 roll has him at Welsby Avenue, Bribie Island, land owner.

comment.author: 32605636@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/96752972@N00] Thanks so much for all that digging into the lives of these three men. We have written a story on our SLQ today blog about this photograph and we're going to do an update with the information you have found - with attribution to you, of course, as the one who has done all the hard work! Look for it in the next few days. blogs.slq.qld.gov.au

comment.author: 96752972@N00
96752972@N00
comment._content:
... and you had so much lovely info at your fingertips. All I did was add in the official stuff. Good to know that Kenneth was the James Kennedy record I spotted in Hawaii.
For the sake of completeness, Glen DOB 7 May 1895, married Ursula May Jones 14 December 1935.
Colin DOB 10 July 1898, Kenneth DOB 2 August 1885

Mum died 12 September 1925. She had married James Kennedy on 1 January 1883. I guess she originated from Denmark.

But thanks anyway.

comment.author: 95216041@N04
comment._content: Hi there, I'm Michelle Kennedy, granddaughter of Glen Kennedy.  Glen and Ursula had one son, Graeme Duff Kennedy (my father) in 1938.  I know some of the family history, but my older sister knows much more having traced the family tree.  I believe she has a box of letters from Kenneth to his mother Sophia from when he was in the States.

comment.author: 96752972@N00
comment._content: Michelle, I saw Graeme Duff Kennedy in the electoral rolls when I was searching, but I was not brave enough to assume the connection (even though I had a gut feeling). Great that you got to see this, and I hope your sister gets in touch with the State Library.

comment.author: 32605636@N06
comment._content: Our thanks to Graham Kennedy, son of Glen who got in contact with us and tied up some loose ends of this story. His dad died in 1978 and is buried at the Mt. Thompson Memorial cemetery. He told us that at the time of his enlistment, his dad worked in Croydon as a storeman. He was a crack shot, as many country lads were at the time and hoped to enlist as a sniper. He also, knew morse code as part of his work and when the army found out about this he ended up being part of the 49th Signals Corps. One of his strong memories was of repairing communications lines in no man's land while trying to avoid enemy fire!

comment.author: 52257493@N00
comment._content: This is a neat use of social media and public records.  SFC MEC SCH DET AIR SVC almost surely means "Sergeant First Class Mechanics School Detachment Air Service" or something similar.  The Army Air Service had Mechanics Schools in San Antonio, TX (Kelly Field) and St. Paul. MN (Overland Building) as of Nov 1918.

comment.author: 32605636@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/mobili] That's another good piece of information to know. Thanks for sharing.
